Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Addressing the Need for Innovative Education of Audio Visual Specialists

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a collaborative project involving Carroll Community College (Award DUE-1600748) and Howard Community College (Award DUE-1600754) in Maryland, and it builds on a previous Advanced Technological Education (ATE) project (Award DUE-0802311) at Lone Star College-Montgomery in Texas. Audio Visual Systems (AVS) specialists are needed to support the specialized communication and presentation needs of businesses and other organizations. AVS specialists are employed in universities, K-12 schools, scientific research centers, conference centers, hotels, theaters, and other venues that have integrated, high-tech communication systems. These technicians require advanced training in industry-specific technologies that support a multitude of presentation venues, which in turn support educational, conference, corporate, entertainment, and other events. The two collaborating colleges will jointly create an innovative AVS program to prepare students for this growing, interdisciplinary field, in which the technology continues to advance and to require deeper knowledge of concepts in science, mathematics, and engineering. The new program will provide a pathway for students, offering certificates, an associate degree, and the option of transferring to a four-year program.

The AAS degree program in Audio Visual Technology Systems (AVTS) will partner with local businesses and other organizations to offer on-the-job training, as well as potential post-graduation employment. Students will receive hands-on instruction in the application of electrical, lighting, and acoustical theories and designs. The program will be led by faculty who have substantial industry experience. Specific objectives of the project are to develop courses and curricula; recruit students into certificate and degree programs; develop and strengthen industry relationships; ensure smooth transitions for students from high schools to the two-year program, and from the two-year program to four-year programs; and disseminate the curriculum and other resources to other community colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was to design and implement a new technology degree and certificate program in order to train future event technicians.  The original creators of this program (while working with industry professionals) noticed a need for innovative education of audiovisual specialists and thus created the new Entertainment Technology program. 

The main outcome of this project then was making sure we had a degree and certificate program that aligned with industry standards as well as the standards of MHEC (Maryland Higher Education Commission.)  MHEC did officially approve of our program and those we have worked with in the industry have acknowledged and approved of our training.

The following is our most updated, Academic Council approved, Program Description and Program Goals:

The purpose of the AAS degree in Entertainment Technology is to prepare students to work as audiovisual specialists and event technicians in a variety of presenting venues such as conference centers, hotels, theaters, houses of worship, sports arenas, resorts, and more!  Student?s multimedia communication skills will strengthen through specialized courses, practicums, and co-ops using industry-specific technology both on campus and in the field.  The small student-to-faculty ratio (usually under 15-1) provides students more opportunities for hands-on learning with quality instruction from industry professionals.

Program Goals:

  1.  Identify types and purposes of audio, lighting, video, and set construction equipment used for live events.
  2. Use industry standard audio, lighting, video, and stet construction equipment for live events.
  3. Apply electrical, lighting, and acoustical theories and designs pertaining to live events.
  4. Engage in technician best practices that support live events through hands-on experience.

We felt it was important to cover the basics in house (or on campus) but also provide opportunities in the field so students were better prepared to enter the workforce.  Below is a list of our required courses for the degree and certificate programs. (Degree seeking students also take several general education credits)

  • ENTEC-101:  Introduction to Entertainment Technology
  • ENTEC-105:  Entertainment Technology Lighting
  • ENTEC-106:  Entertainment Technology Audio
  • ENTEC-107:  Entertainment Technology Video     
  • ENTEC-220:  Entertainment Technology Cooperative Education 1
  • ENTEC-221:  Entertainment Technology Cooperative Education 2
  • ENTEC-222:  Entertainment Technology Cooperative Education 3
  • ENTEC-230:  Entertainment Technology Capstone Project

Each of our ENTEC Cooperative Education courses place the student in a new work environment.  We continuously work to find new opportunities for them so they get a well rounded education.  Our current businesses are EventEQ (an event business in Columbia, MD), The Community Media Center (which features broadcast equipment), Carroll Arts Center (a local theater rental house), and Glenelg Country School (a private school with a top of the line theater.)  While most of the students' credit hours are consumed by working for these individual companies, there are also projects and reports they must complete outside of their working hours.  We have found communication with their work supervisors easily obtainable and our students value the hands-on learning.

Additional courses required:

  • THTR-115:  Stagecraft
  • THTR-125 and THTR-126:  Theatre Practicums
  • THTR-145:  Stage Management
  • THTR-245:  Production Management
  • CAD-101:  Introduction to Computer-Aided Drafting/Design

To ensure proper training could occur in the above-mentioned courses, new equipment was needed.  We were able to purchase high-end equipment similar to instruments students would be using in the field.  One of the best pieces was a mini lighting lab.  While our students have several opportunities to use the equipment in our actual theater, it is not always available.  This lighting lab is of miniature size making instruction and learning more accessible. 

As educators, we know that our students will become more confident when given more opportunities to learn, work with the equipment, and work in professional settings; but one of our most unexpected outcomes to date was a student getting to experience attending a conference and the impact that made on her.  This project provided her the opportunity to attend the ATE conference; an opportunity that most sophomores don't get even at a four year college. 

From the student, "The opportunity to participate in the ATE conference helped me to better understand the significance of my field and what I am learning in this program.  I enjoyed having the opportunity to engage educators outside of my school about ENTEC.  The program seemed unique to the individuals I discussed it with.  Many of the people I spoke to expressed regret that their institution does not offer a program that touches on these topics and skills.  The existence of the ATE program and the conferences that it hosts indicate that people notice that what I value learning is something valuable to learn and teach.  That's an extremely important message to send, maybe even particularly important in community colleges.  It is important for students to know that their education is valued to such an extent and that their goals are important."
